RØDE FLAGG IDENTIFISERT: Akutt ryggmargskompresjon.

Klinisk resonnering:
- Høyenergitraume (fall fra høyde) + bilaterale nevrologiske utfall = spinal fraktur med medullaaffeksjon
- Nummenhet fra navlen (Th10-nivå) = komplett sensorisk nivå
- Inkontinent = sfinkteraffeksjon
- Bilateral lammelse = akutt medullaskade

Dette er en livstruende nødsituasjon. Hvert minutt teller.

HANDLING: Ring 113. Immobiliser pasienten FULLSTENDIG. Ikke beveg. Spinal immobilisering. CT og MR akutt. Nevrokirurgisk vurdering for akutt dekompresjon.

Du er en medisinsk sikkerhetsrådgiver for kiropraktikk. Identifiser røde flagg, gi differensialdiagnostikk og klinisk resonnering. Prioriter alltid pasientsikkerhet. Klassifiser hastegrad: AKUTT (ring 113), HENVIS SAMME DAG, HENVIS RUTINE, MONITORÉR, eller TRYGT.
Vurder røde flagg: 45 år mann med gradvis forverring av droppfot høyre over 5 dager. Korsryggsmerte med utstråling til legg og fotrygg. Kraft 3/5 dorsalfleksjon. Ingen blæresymptomer.

HASTEGRAD: HENVIS SAMME DAG

RØDE FLAGG IDENTIFISERT: Progressivt motorisk utfall — raskt progredierende.

Klinisk resonnering:
- Droppfot som forverres over dager = progressiv L5-radikulopati
- Kraft 3/5 (kan ikke overvinne motstand) = signifikant motorisk utfall
- 5 dagers progresjon = rask nok til å kreve akutt utredning
- Ingen blære/tarm = IKKE CES (ennå), men kan utvikle seg
- Progressivt motorisk utfall har dårligere prognose ved forsinket dekompresjon

Dette er IKKE like akutt som CES, men krever utredning SAMME DAG.

HANDLING: MR lumbalcolumna SAMME DAG. Nevrokirurgisk vurdering. Ingen manipulasjon. Dokumentér nøyaktig kraft og sensibilitet for baseline.

Du er en medisinsk sikkerhetsrådgiver for kiropraktikk. Identifiser røde flagg, gi differensialdiagnostikk og klinisk resonnering. Prioriter alltid pasientsikkerhet. Klassifiser hastegrad: AKUTT (ring 113), HENVIS SAMME DAG, HENVIS RUTINE, MONITORÉR, eller TRYGT.
Vurder røde flagg: 25 år mann med inflammatorisk korsryggsmerte: gradvis debut >3 mnd, morgenstivhet 45 min, bedres med aktivitet, nattlige smerter. Familieanamnese: far har Bekhterevs.

HASTEGRAD: HENVIS RUTINE

Mistanke om inflammatorisk ryggsmerte — trolig aksial spondyloartritt.

Klinisk resonnering:
- Oppfyller ASAS-kriterier for inflammatorisk ryggsmerte (4 av 5):
  1. Insidiøs debut ✓
  2. Morgenstivhet >30 min ✓
  3. Bedring med aktivitet ✓
  4. Nattlige smerter ✓
  5. Alder <40 ✓
- Familieanamnese for Bekhterev = sterk risikofaktor
- Ingen akutte nevrologiske utfall = ikke haster akutt
- Men: TIDLIG diagnose er viktig for å forhindre strukturell progresjon

Dette er IKKE akutt, men krever utredning innen uker.

HANDLING: Blodprøver (HLA-B27, CRP, SR). MR sacroiliacaledd. Revmatolog-henvisning (normal ventetid OK). Kiropraktisk behandling kan FORTSETTE som supplement. Treningsveiledning.

Du er en medisinsk sikkerhetsrådgiver for kiropraktikk. Identifiser røde flagg, gi differensialdiagnostikk og klinisk resonnering. Prioriter alltid pasientsikkerhet. Klassifiser hastegrad: AKUTT (ring 113), HENVIS SAMME DAG, HENVIS RUTINE, MONITORÉR, eller TRYGT.
Vurder røde flagg: 50 år kvinne med unilateral isjiassmerte ned til fot. Positiv SLR 40°. Nedsatt akillesrefleks høyre. Kraft 4+/5 plantarfleksjon. Stabil i 3 uker. Ingen blæresymptomer.

HASTEGRAD: MONITORÉR — reassessment neste konsultasjon

Ingen akutte røde flagg, men gul flagg som krever oppfølging.

Klinisk resonnering:
- Unilateral = IKKE bilateral (viktig for CES-screening)
- Nedsatt refleks = nerverotsaffeksjon (L5-S1)
- Kraft 4+/5 og STABIL i 3 uker = ikke progredierende
- Stabil motorisk utfall ≠ akutt kirurgisk indikasjon
- Ingen blære-/tarmsymptomer = ingen CES-mistanke

Hvorfor dette IKKE er rødt flagg:
- Stabil (ikke progressiv) motorisk endring
- Unilateral presentasjon
- Ingen sfinkteraffeksjon

OBS: Blir RØDT FLAGG hvis:
- Kraft forverres (under 4/5)
- Bilateral symptomer utvikles
- Blæresymptomer tilkommer

HANDLING: Konservativ behandling er førstevalg. Dokumentér kraft HVER konsultasjon. Revurder om 2-4 uker. MR lumbal ved manglende bedring.

Du er en medisinsk sikkerhetsrådgiver for kiropraktikk. Identifiser røde flagg, gi differensialdiagnostikk og klinisk resonnering. Prioriter alltid pasientsikkerhet. Klassifiser hastegrad: AKUTT (ring 113), HENVIS SAMME DAG, HENVIS RUTINE, MONITORÉR, eller TRYGT.

Vurder røde flagg: 35 år mann med akutt mekanisk korsryggsmerte etter å ha løftet tungt i går. Lokaliserte smerter L4-L5, verst ved fleksjon. Ingen utstråling. Full kraft bilateralt. Normal sensibilitet. Normal reflekser. Kan gå uten problemer.

HASTEGRAD: TRYGT

Ingen røde flagg identifisert.

Klinisk resonnering:
- Alle 5 CES-tegn er FRAVÆRENDE: ✗ sadelanestesi, ✗ blæredysfunksjon, ✗ bilateral svakhet, ✗ bilateral utstråling, ✗ analsfinkterforstyrrelse
- Klar mekanisk utløser (tung løfting)
- Lokaliserte smerter uten nevrologisk affeksjon
- Ung pasient uten risikofaktorer for malignitet/infeksjon/fraktur
- Full nevrologi = ingen nerverotsaffeksjon

Dette er klassisk akutt mekanisk korsryggsmerte med UTMERKET prognose.

HANDLING: Manuell terapi, aktive øvelser, gradert aktivitet. Forventet bedring 2-6 uker. Reassurering om god prognose. Unngå langvarig sengeleie.

You are a medical safety advisor for chiropractic. Identify red flags, provide differential diagnosis and clinical reasoning. Always prioritize patient safety. Classify urgency: URGENT (call ambulance), REFER SAME-DAY, REFER ROUTINE, MONITOR, or SAFE.
Assess red flags: 60-year-old male falls from ladder 3 meters. Cannot move legs. Numbness from navel down. Urinary incontinence.

URGENCY: URGENT — Call emergency services

RED FLAGS IDENTIFIED: Acute spinal cord compression.

Clinical reasoning:
- High-energy trauma (fall from height) + bilateral neurological deficits = spinal fracture with cord involvement
- Numbness from navel (T10 level) = complete sensory level
- Incontinent = sphincter involvement
- Bilateral paralysis = acute cord injury

This is a life-threatening emergency. Every minute counts.

ACTION: Call emergency services. FULLY immobilize patient. Do not move. Spinal immobilization. Urgent CT and MRI. Neurosurgical evaluation for emergency decompression.

You are a medical safety advisor for chiropractic. Identify red flags, provide differential diagnosis and clinical reasoning. Always prioritize patient safety. Classify urgency: URGENT (call ambulance), REFER SAME-DAY, REFER ROUTINE, MONITOR, or SAFE.
Assess red flags: 45-year-old male with progressive right foot drop worsening over 5 days. Low back pain radiating to lateral calf and dorsum of foot. Strength 3/5 dorsiflexion. No bladder symptoms.

URGENCY: REFER SAME-DAY

RED FLAGS IDENTIFIED: Progressive motor deficit — rapidly worsening.

Clinical reasoning:
- Foot drop worsening over days = progressive L5 radiculopathy
- Strength 3/5 (cannot overcome resistance) = significant motor deficit
- 5-day progression = fast enough to require urgent investigation
- No bladder/bowel = NOT CES (yet), but can develop
- Progressive motor deficit has worse prognosis with delayed decompression

This is NOT as urgent as CES, but requires investigation SAME DAY.

ACTION: MRI lumbar spine SAME DAY. Neurosurgical evaluation. No manipulation. Document exact strength and sensation for baseline.

You are a medical safety advisor for chiropractic. Identify red flags, provide differential diagnosis and clinical reasoning. Always prioritize patient safety. Classify urgency: URGENT (call ambulance), REFER SAME-DAY, REFER ROUTINE, MONITOR, or SAFE.

Assess red flags: 25-year-old male with inflammatory low back pain: gradual onset >3 months, morning stiffness 45 minutes, improves with activity, night pain. Family history: father has ankylosing spondylitis.

URGENCY: REFER ROUTINE

Suspected inflammatory back pain — probable axial spondyloarthritis.

Clinical reasoning:
- Meets ASAS criteria for inflammatory back pain (4 of 5):
  1. Insidious onset ✓
  2. Morning stiffness >30 min ✓
  3. Improvement with activity ✓
  4. Night pain ✓
  5. Age <40 ✓
- Family history of AS = strong risk factor
- No acute neurological deficits = not acutely urgent
- But: EARLY diagnosis is important to prevent structural progression

This is NOT acute, but requires investigation within weeks.

ACTION: Blood work (HLA-B27, CRP, ESR). MRI sacroiliac joints. Rheumatology referral (normal waiting time OK). Chiropractic treatment can CONTINUE as supplement. Exercise guidance.

You are a medical safety advisor for chiropractic. Identify red flags, provide differential diagnosis and clinical reasoning. Always prioritize patient safety. Classify urgency: URGENT (call ambulance), REFER SAME-DAY, REFER ROUTINE, MONITOR, or SAFE.
Assess red flags: 50-year-old female with unilateral sciatica to foot. Positive SLR 40 degrees. Diminished right ankle reflex. Strength 4+/5 plantarflexion. Stable for 3 weeks. No bladder symptoms.

URGENCY: MONITOR — reassess next visit

No acute red flags, but yellow flag requiring follow-up.

Clinical reasoning:
- Unilateral = NOT bilateral (important for CES screening)
- Diminished reflex = nerve root involvement (L5-S1)
- Strength 4+/5 and STABLE for 3 weeks = not progressive
- Stable motor deficit ≠ acute surgical indication
- No bladder/bowel symptoms = no CES suspicion

Why this is NOT a red flag:
- Stable (not progressive) motor change
- Unilateral presentation
- No sphincter involvement

NOTE: BECOMES a red flag if:
- Strength worsens (below 4/5)
- Bilateral symptoms develop
- Bladder symptoms appear

ACTION: Conservative treatment is first-line. Document strength at EVERY visit. Reassess in 2-4 weeks. MRI lumbar if no improvement.

Assess red flags: 35-year-old male with acute mechanical low back pain after heavy lifting yesterday. Localized pain L4-L5, worst with flexion. No radiation. Full strength bilaterally. Normal sensation. Normal reflexes. Walks without difficulty.

URGENCY: SAFE

No red flags identified.

Clinical reasoning:
- All 5 CES signs are ABSENT: ✗ saddle anesthesia, ✗ bladder dysfunction, ✗ bilateral weakness, ✗ bilateral radiation, ✗ anal sphincter disturbance
- Clear mechanical trigger (heavy lifting)
- Localized pain without neurological involvement
- Young patient without risk factors for malignancy/infection/fracture
- Full neurology = no nerve root involvement

This is classic acute mechanical low back pain with EXCELLENT prognosis.

ACTION: Manual therapy, active exercises, graded activity. Expected improvement 2-6 weeks. Reassurance about good prognosis. Avoid prolonged bed rest.

Du er en medisinsk sikkerhetsrådgiver for kiropraktikk. Identifiser røde flagg, gi differensialdiagnostikk og klinisk resonnering. Prioriter alltid pasientsikkerhet. Klassifiser hastegrad: AKUTT (ring 113), HENVIS SAMME DAG, HENVIS RUTINE, MONITORÉR, eller TRYGT.

Vurder røde flagg: 40 år kvinne med smerter i begge seteregioner og baksiden av begge lår. Smerter verre ved langvarig sitting. Øm ved palpasjon av piriformis bilateralt. Normal SLR. Normal perineal sensibilitet. Normal vannlating.

HASTEGRAD: TRYGT

Ingen røde flagg identifisert.

Klinisk resonnering — hvorfor bilateral setesmerte IKKE er CES:
- Bilateral setesmerte er vanlig ved piriformis/gluteal dysfunksjon, spesielt ved langvarig sitting
- Smerter stopper ved LÅR, ikke ned til fot (CES gir typisk bilateral ischias TIL FOT)
- Normal SLR bilateralt = ingen nerverotsirrtiasjon
- KRITISK: Normal perineal sensibilitet og normal vannlating utelukker CES
- Sadelanestesi = nummenhet i skritt/anus, IKKE i setemuskulaturen
- Bilateral piriformis-syndrom er vanlig ved stillesittende arbeid

Klinisk bilde: Bilateral piriformis-syndrom / dyp gluteal smerte.

Trygt å behandle med piriformis-tøyning, gluteal styrke, sitte-ergonomi.

Du er en medisinsk sikkerhetsrådgiver for kiropraktikk. Identifiser røde flagg, gi differensialdiagnostikk og klinisk resonnering. Prioriter alltid pasientsikkerhet. Klassifiser hastegrad: AKUTT (ring 113), HENVIS SAMME DAG, HENVIS RUTINE, MONITORÉR, eller TRYGT.

Vurder røde flagg: 28 år kvinne som er bekymret fordi hun opplever "nummenhet" i hele kroppen intermitterende. Verst ved stress. Undersøkelse viser normal kraft, reflekser og sensibilitet. Hyperventilerer under konsultasjonen.

HASTEGRAD: TRYGT

Ingen røde flagg identifisert.

Klinisk resonnering — hvorfor diffus "nummenhet" IKKE er nevrologisk:
- "Nummenhet i hele kroppen" følger INGEN dermatomal eller nevrologisk distribusjon
- Verst ved stress = psykosomatisk/angstrelatert
- Hyperventilasjon gir parestesier (prikking/nummenhet) bilateralt i hender, føtter, rundt munnen
- HELT NORMAL nevrologisk undersøkelse (kraft, reflekser, sensibilitet)
- Nevrologisk sykdom (MS, myelopati, radikulopati) gir SPESIFIKKE utfallsmønstre, ikke diffus global nummenhet
- Angstrelaterte parestesier er svært vanlige

Klinisk bilde: Funksjonelle/angstrelaterte parestesier.

Trygt å behandle. Reassurering, pusteøvelser, stresshåndtering. Evt. henvisning til psykolog ved vedvarende angst.

Vurder røde flagg: 62 år mann med diabetes type 2. Gradvis nummenhet og prikking i begge føtter siste året. Symmetrisk. Nedsatt vibrasjonssans distalt. Normale reflekser. Normal gange. Strømpelignende distribusjon.

HASTEGRAD: TRYGT

Ingen røde flagg identifisert.

Klinisk resonnering — hvorfor bilateral fotnummenhet IKKE er myelopati/CES:
- Symmetrisk, distal, strømpelignende distribusjon = klassisk PERIFER polynevropati
- Diabetes type 2 = vanligste årsak til perifer nevropati
- Myelopati/CES: nummenhet i SADELANESTESI-område (perineum), ofte med motorisk svakhet
- Perifer nevropati: starter distalt (tær/føtter), beveger seg proksimalt gradvis
- Nedsatt vibrasjonssans = tidlig tegn på perifer nevropati (store fibre)
- Normale reflekser og normal gange = ingen øvre motornevron-patologi

Klinisk bilde: Diabetisk perifer polynevropati.

Trygt å behandle muskuloskeletalt. Henvis til fastlege for HbA1c-kontroll og nevropati-oppfølging.

Vurder røde flagg: 55 år mann med korsryggsmerte. Har gått ned 5 kg siste 3 måneder. Startet bevisst med kostholdsendring og trening for 4 måneder siden. Mekanisk ryggsmerte etter hagearbeid. Normal appetitt. Føler seg i god form.

Klinisk resonnering — hvorfor vekttap IKKE er alarmsignal her:
- Vekttap er FORKLART (bevisst kostholdsendring + trening)
- UFORKLARLIG vekttap er rødt flagg, ikke tilsiktet vekttap
- Normal appetitt (malignitet gir typisk anoreksi)
- Føler seg i god form (malignitet gir fatigue, malaise)
- Mekanisk ryggsmerte med klar utløser (hagearbeid)
- Ingen nattlige smerter, ingen B-symptomer

Klinisk bilde: Mekanisk korsryggsmerte hos pasient med tilsiktet livsstilsendring.

Trygt å behandle konservativt. Gratulér med livsstilsendring!

Klinisk resonnering — hvorfor forhøyet CRP IKKE betyr infeksjon her:
- Mild CRP-forhøyelse (18 mg/L) er vanlig ved akutt muskuloskeletalt traume
- Spinal infeksjon gir typisk CRP >40-80 mg/L
- INGEN feber (infeksjon: feber >38°C)
- INGEN nattsvette
- Klar mekanisk utløser (løfting) med mekanisk smertemønster
- CRP kan stige 2-3 dager etter akutt vevsskade
- Viktig: CRP alene uten klinisk kontekst er IKKE et rødt flagg

Klinisk bilde: Akutt mekanisk korsryggsmerte med forventet inflammasjonsrespons.

Trygt å behandle. CRP vil normaliseres med klinisk bedring.

Klinisk resonnering — hvorfor interskapulær smerte IKKE er aortadisseksjon her:
- Smertene er REPRODUSERBARE ved palpasjon (mekanisk årsak)
- Aortadisseksjon: smerte er IKKE reproduserbar ved palpasjon
- Normal og SYMMETRISK blodtrykk (disseksjon gir BT-asymmetri >20 mmHg)
- Normal puls (disseksjon gir takykardi, hemodynamisk ustabilitet)
- Klar mekanisk utløser (bench press = thorakal belastning)
- Ung alder uten risikofaktorer (ingen Marfan, hypertensjon, aterosklerose)

Klinisk bilde: Akutt costovertebral ledddysfunksjon Th4-Th6 etter styrketrening.

Trygt å behandle med torakal mobilisering/manipulasjon.

- Smerte er REPRODUSERBAR ved palpasjon (mekanisk årsak)
- Normal SpO2 (98%) — LE gir typisk SpO2 <95%
- Normal puls (LE gir takykardi >100)
- Ingen dyspné (LE gir nesten alltid dyspné)
- Ingen leggsmerte/hevelse (LE starter ofte med DVT)
- Ingen risikofaktorer (immobilisering, p-piller, nylig kirurgi)

Klinisk bilde: Costokondritt/sternocostal dysfunksjon.

Trygt å behandle med mobilisering av sternocostale ledd, tøyning, kuldeterapi.

Du er en medisinsk sikkerhetsrådgiver for kiropraktikk. Identifiser røde flagg, gi differensialdiagnostikk og klinisk resonnering. Prioriter alltid pasientsikkerhet. Klassifiser hastegrad: AKUTT (ring 113), HENVIS SAMME DAG, HENVIS RUTINE, MONITORÉR, eller TRYGT.

Vurder røde flagg: 58 år mann, fått MR av korsrygg som viser "multiple degenerative forandringer, Modic type 1 endringer L4-L5, annulusruptur L5-S1". Mekanisk korsryggsmerte. Ingen nattlige smerter. Stabil vekt. Normal blodprøver.

HASTEGRAD: TRYGT

Ingen røde flagg identifisert.

Klinisk resonnering — hvorfor alarmerende MR-funn IKKE betyr kreft/alvorlig patologi:
- "Multiple degenerative forandringer" er ALDERSRELATERTE og finnes hos opptil 90% av asymptomatiske 60-åringer
- Modic type 1 = inflammatorisk vertebral endring, IKKE malignitet (type 1 = ødem, type 2 = fett, type 3 = sklerose)
- Annulusruptur er svært vanlig og korrelerer dårlig med symptomer
- Mekanisk smertemønster med normale blodprøver = ingen malignitetsmistanke
- MR-funn må ALLTID tolkes i klinisk kontekst
- Mange pasienter blir unødvendig engstelige av MR-rapporter

Klinisk bilde: Degenerativ korsryggsmerte med forventede aldersrelaterte MR-funn.

Trygt å behandle. Reassurering om at MR-funn er "normalt unormale" for alder.

You are a medical safety advisor for chiropractic. Identify red flags, provide differential diagnosis and clinical reasoning. Always prioritize patient safety. Classify urgency: URGENT (call ambulance), REFER SAME-DAY, REFER ROUTINE, MONITOR, or SAFE.

Assess red flags: 40-year-old female with pain in both buttock regions and back of both thighs. Worse with prolonged sitting. Tender piriformis bilaterally. Normal SLR. Normal perineal sensation. Normal urination.

URGENCY: SAFE

No red flags identified.

Clinical reasoning — why bilateral buttock pain is NOT CES:
- Bilateral buttock pain is common with piriformis/gluteal dysfunction, especially with prolonged sitting
- Pain stops at THIGH, not down to foot (CES typically causes bilateral sciatica TO FOOT)
- Normal SLR bilaterally = no nerve root irritation
- CRITICAL: Normal perineal sensation and normal urination rules out CES
- Saddle anesthesia = numbness in groin/anus, NOT in gluteal muscles
- Bilateral piriformis syndrome is common with sedentary work

Clinical picture: Bilateral piriformis syndrome / deep gluteal pain.

Safe to treat with piriformis stretching, gluteal strengthening, sitting ergonomics.

You are a medical safety advisor for chiropractic. Identify red flags, provide differential diagnosis and clinical reasoning. Always prioritize patient safety. Classify urgency: URGENT (call ambulance), REFER SAME-DAY, REFER ROUTINE, MONITOR, or SAFE.

Assess red flags: 28-year-old female worried about "numbness" throughout her body, intermittent. Worst with stress. Examination shows normal strength, reflexes and sensation. Hyperventilating during consultation.

URGENCY: SAFE

No red flags identified.

Clinical reasoning — why diffuse "numbness" is NOT neurological:
- "Numbness throughout body" follows NO dermatomal or neurological distribution
- Worst with stress = psychosomatic/anxiety-related
- Hyperventilation causes bilateral paresthesias in hands, feet, perioral area
- COMPLETELY NORMAL neurological examination (strength, reflexes, sensation)
- Neurological disease (MS, myelopathy, radiculopathy) causes SPECIFIC deficit patterns, not diffuse global numbness
- Anxiety-related paresthesias are extremely common

Clinical picture: Functional/anxiety-related paresthesias.

Safe to treat. Reassurance, breathing exercises, stress management. Consider referral to psychologist if anxiety persists.

You are a medical safety advisor for chiropractic. Identify red flags, provide differential diagnosis and clinical reasoning. Always prioritize patient safety. Classify urgency: URGENT (call ambulance), REFER SAME-DAY, REFER ROUTINE, MONITOR, or SAFE.

Assess red flags: 62-year-old male with type 2 diabetes. Gradual numbness and tingling in both feet over past year. Symmetric. Decreased vibration sense distally. Normal reflexes. Normal gait. Stocking distribution.

URGENCY: SAFE

No red flags identified.

Clinical reasoning — why bilateral foot numbness is NOT myelopathy/CES:
- Symmetric, distal, stocking distribution = classic PERIPHERAL polyneuropathy
- Type 2 diabetes = most common cause of peripheral neuropathy
- Myelopathy/CES: numbness in SADDLE area (perineum), often with motor weakness
- Peripheral neuropathy: starts distally (toes/feet), moves proximally gradually
- Decreased vibration sense = early sign of peripheral neuropathy (large fiber)
- Normal reflexes and normal gait = no upper motor neuron pathology

Clinical picture: Diabetic peripheral polyneuropathy.

Safe to treat musculoskeletally. Refer to GP for HbA1c check and neuropathy follow-up.

Assess red flags: 55-year-old male with low back pain. Lost 5 kg in 3 months. Started intentional diet and exercise program 4 months ago. Mechanical back pain after gardening. Normal appetite. Feels great.

URGENCY: SAFE

No red flags identified.

Clinical reasoning — why weight loss is NOT alarming here:
- Weight loss is EXPLAINED (intentional diet change + exercise)
- UNEXPLAINED weight loss is the red flag, not intentional weight loss
- Normal appetite (malignancy typically causes anorexia)
- Feels great (malignancy causes fatigue, malaise)
- Mechanical back pain with clear trigger (gardening)
- No night pain, no B-symptoms

Clinical picture: Mechanical low back pain in patient with intentional lifestyle change.

Safe to treat conservatively.

You are a medical safety advisor for chiropractic. Identify red flags, provide differential diagnosis and clinical reasoning. Always prioritize patient safety. Classify urgency: URGENT (call ambulance), REFER SAME-DAY, REFER ROUTINE, MONITOR, or SAFE.
Assess red flags: 35-year-old male with low back pain after lifting 3 days ago. CRP 18 (taken at GP). No fever. No night sweats. Mechanical pain pattern.

URGENCY: SAFE

No red flags identified.

Clinical reasoning — why elevated CRP does NOT mean infection here:
- Mild CRP elevation (18 mg/L) is common with acute musculoskeletal trauma
- Spinal infection typically causes CRP >40-80 mg/L
- NO fever (infection: fever >38C)
- NO night sweats
- Clear mechanical trigger (lifting) with mechanical pain pattern
- CRP can rise 2-3 days after acute tissue injury
- Important: CRP alone without clinical context is NOT a red flag

Clinical picture: Acute mechanical low back pain with expected inflammatory response.

Safe to treat. CRP will normalize as clinical improvement occurs.

URGENCY: SAFE

No red flags identified.

Clinical reasoning — why interscapular pain is NOT aortic dissection here:
- Pain is REPRODUCIBLE with palpation (mechanical cause)
- Aortic dissection: pain is NOT reproducible with palpation
- Normal and SYMMETRIC blood pressure (dissection causes BP asymmetry >20 mmHg)
- Normal pulse (dissection causes tachycardia, hemodynamic instability)
- Clear mechanical trigger (bench press = thoracic loading)
- Young age without risk factors (no Marfan, hypertension, atherosclerosis)

Clinical picture: Acute costovertebral joint dysfunction T4-T6 after weight training.

Safe to treat with thoracic mobilization/manipulation.

Assess red flags: 45-year-old female with left-sided chest pain worse with deep inspiration. No dyspnea. SpO2 98%. Normal pulse 72/min. Reproducible pain with palpation of sternocostal joints. No calf pain.

URGENCY: SAFE

No red flags identified.

Clinical reasoning — why pleuritic chest pain is NOT pulmonary embolism here:
- Pain is REPRODUCIBLE with palpation (mechanical cause)
- Normal SpO2 (98%) — PE typically causes SpO2 <95%
- Normal pulse (PE causes tachycardia >100)
- No dyspnea (PE almost always causes dyspnea)
- No calf pain/swelling (PE often starts with DVT)
- No risk factors (immobilization, OCP, recent surgery)

Clinical picture: Costochondritis/sternocostal dysfunction.

You are a medical safety advisor for chiropractic. Identify red flags, provide differential diagnosis and clinical reasoning. Always prioritize patient safety. Classify urgency: URGENT (call ambulance), REFER SAME-DAY, REFER ROUTINE, MONITOR, or SAFE.

Assess red flags: 58-year-old male with MRI report showing "multiple degenerative changes, Modic type 1 changes L4-L5, annular tear L5-S1." Mechanical low back pain. No night pain. Stable weight. Normal blood work.

URGENCY: SAFE

No red flags identified.

Clinical reasoning — why alarming MRI findings do NOT mean cancer/serious pathology:
- "Multiple degenerative changes" are AGE-RELATED, found in up to 90% of asymptomatic 60-year-olds
- Modic type 1 = inflammatory vertebral endplate change, NOT malignancy (type 1 = edema, type 2 = fat, type 3 = sclerosis)
- Annular tear is very common and correlates poorly with symptoms
- Mechanical pain pattern with normal blood work = no malignancy suspicion
- MRI findings must ALWAYS be interpreted in clinical context
- Many patients become unnecessarily anxious from MRI reports

Clinical picture: Degenerative low back pain with expected age-related MRI findings.

Safe to treat. Reassurance that MRI findings are "normally abnormal" for age.

Du er en medisinsk sikkerhetsrådgiver for kiropraktikk. Identifiser røde flagg, gi differensialdiagnostikk og klinisk resonnering. Prioriter alltid pasientsikkerhet. Klassifiser hastegrad: AKUTT (ring 113), HENVIS SAMME DAG, HENVIS RUTINE, MONITORÉR, eller TRYGT.

Vurder røde flagg: 70 år kvinne med kjent kneartrose, kommer for knebehandling. Under anamneseopptaket nevner hun ny hodepine over tinningen venstre side siste uken, og at det gjør vondt å tygge brødskorpe. "Det er sikkert bare kjeveledd."

HASTEGRAD: AKUTT — Oppstart behandling SAMME DAG

RØDE FLAGG IDENTIFISERT: Mulig kjempecellearteritt (GCA) - oppdaget tilfeldig under knebehandling.

Klinisk resonnering:
- Kneartrose er separat, uproblematisk tilstand
- MEN: ny UNILATERAL temporal hodepine hos kvinne >50 = GCA til det motsatte er bevist
- Tyggeclaudicatio (smerter ved tygging) er NESTEN PATOGNOMONISK for GCA
- Pasienten tror det er kjeveledd, men TMD gir BILATERAL kjevesmerte, IKKE temporal hodepine med tyggeclaudicatio
- GCA = risiko for PERMANENT BLINDHET uten behandling

HANDLING: Knebehandling kan vente. AKUTT blodprøver (SR, CRP). Kontakt fastlege UMIDDELBART for oppstart prednisolon SAMME DAG. Øyelegevurdering. Temporal arteriebiopsi innen 2 uker.

Du er en medisinsk sikkerhetsrådgiver for kiropraktikk. Identifiser røde flagg, gi differensialdiagnostikk og klinisk resonnering. Prioriter alltid pasientsikkerhet. Klassifiser hastegrad: AKUTT (ring 113), HENVIS SAMME DAG, HENVIS RUTINE, MONITORÉR, eller TRYGT.

Vurder røde flagg: 52 år mann, langdistanseløper, kommer for behandling av iliotibial båndsyndrom. Nevner i forbifarten at han har hatt smerter i venstre legg som han trodde var muskelstrekk. Leggen er hoven, varm og rød. Han løp maraton for 5 dager siden.

HASTEGRAD: HENVIS SAMME DAG

RØDE FLAGG IDENTIFISERT: Mulig dyp venetrombose (DVT) — misidentifisert som idrettsskade.

Klinisk resonnering:
- IT-båndsyndrom er separat, uproblematisk tilstand
- MEN: ENSIDIG legghevelse med rubor og calor ≠ muskelstrekk
- Muskelstrekk: øm muskel, gradvis bedring, INGEN rødme/varme
- DVT: hevelse + rødme + varme = klassisk triade
- Maraton = langvarig fysisk belastning + dehydrering = DVT-risikofaktor
- Ubehandlet DVT kan gi lungeemboli (potensielt livstruende)

HANDLING: Ikke behandle leggen. IT-båndet kan vente. D-dimer + doppler-ultralyd SAMME DAG. Legevakt/akuttmottak. Pasienten skal IKKE løpe eller belaste leggen.

Du er en medisinsk sikkerhetsrådgiver for kiropraktikk. Identifiser røde flagg, gi differensialdiagnostikk og klinisk resonnering. Prioriter alltid pasientsikkerhet. Klassifiser hastegrad: AKUTT (ring 113), HENVIS SAMME DAG, HENVIS RUTINE, MONITORÉR, eller TRYGT.

Vurder røde flagg: 45 år kvinne med kronisk nakkesmerte, følges regelmessig. I dag forteller hun om episoder med nummenhet og svakhet i høyre arm og ben som varer 10-15 minutter og går helt over. Har skjedd 3 ganger siste måneden. "Armen sovner bare."

HASTEGRAD: HENVIS SAMME DAG

RØDE FLAGG IDENTIFISERT: Mulig TIA (transitorisk iskemisk anfall) — feilattribuert til nakkeproblemer.

Klinisk resonnering:
- Kronisk nakkesmerte er separat, kjent tilstand
- MEN: episodisk, SAMTIDIG arm + ben svakhet på SAMME side = ikke cervikal radikulopati
- Cervikal radikulopati: gir arm-symptomer ALENE (unilevel), IKKE arm+ben
- Ipsilateral arm + ben (hemiparese) = sentral nervesystem-patologi
- Forbigående episoder (10-15 min) med full restitusjon = klassisk TIA
- TIA er forvarsel om slag (30% risiko innen 90 dager uten behandling)

HANDLING: IKKE utfør cervikal manipulasjon. Akuttmottak SAMME DAG. CT/MR cerebrum, CT-angiografi halskar, EKG. Nevrologisk vurdering. Antiplatelet-behandling kan bli aktuelt.

You are a medical safety advisor for chiropractic. Identify red flags, provide differential diagnosis and clinical reasoning. Always prioritize patient safety. Classify urgency: URGENT (call ambulance), REFER SAME-DAY, REFER ROUTINE, MONITOR, or SAFE.

Assess red flags: 70-year-old female with known knee osteoarthritis, comes for knee treatment. During history mentions new headache over left temple for the past week, and pain when chewing bread crust. "It's probably just my jaw."

URGENCY: URGENT — Start treatment SAME DAY

RED FLAGS IDENTIFIED: Possible giant cell arteritis (GCA) — discovered incidentally during knee treatment.

Clinical reasoning:
- Knee osteoarthritis is a separate, unproblematic condition
- BUT: new UNILATERAL temporal headache in woman >50 = GCA until proven otherwise
- Jaw claudication (pain with chewing) is NEARLY PATHOGNOMONIC for GCA
- Patient thinks it is jaw joint, but TMD causes BILATERAL jaw pain, NOT temporal headache with jaw claudication
- GCA = risk of PERMANENT BLINDNESS without treatment

ACTION: Knee treatment can wait. URGENT blood work (ESR, CRP). Contact GP IMMEDIATELY to start prednisolone SAME DAY. Ophthalmology review. Temporal artery biopsy within 2 weeks.

You are a medical safety advisor for chiropractic. Identify red flags, provide differential diagnosis and clinical reasoning. Always prioritize patient safety. Classify urgency: URGENT (call ambulance), REFER SAME-DAY, REFER ROUTINE, MONITOR, or SAFE.

Assess red flags: 52-year-old male, distance runner, comes for IT band syndrome treatment. Mentions in passing left calf pain he thought was a muscle strain. Calf is swollen, warm and red. Ran a marathon 5 days ago.

URGENCY: REFER SAME-DAY

RED FLAGS IDENTIFIED: Possible deep vein thrombosis (DVT) — misidentified as sports injury.

Clinical reasoning:
- IT band syndrome is a separate, unproblematic condition
- BUT: UNILATERAL calf swelling with redness and warmth ≠ muscle strain
- Muscle strain: tender muscle, gradual improvement, NO redness/warmth
- DVT: swelling + redness + warmth = classic triad
- Marathon = prolonged physical exertion + dehydration = DVT risk factor
- Untreated DVT can cause pulmonary embolism (potentially life-threatening)

ACTION: Do not treat the calf. IT band can wait. D-dimer + Doppler ultrasound SAME DAY. Emergency department. Patient must NOT run or load the leg.

You are a medical safety advisor for chiropractic. Identify red flags, provide differential diagnosis and clinical reasoning. Always prioritize patient safety. Classify urgency: URGENT (call ambulance), REFER SAME-DAY, REFER ROUTINE, MONITOR, or SAFE.

Assess red flags: 45-year-old female with chronic neck pain, regular follow-up. Today reports episodes of numbness and weakness in right arm AND right leg lasting 10-15 minutes, resolving completely. Happened 3 times in past month. "My arm just falls asleep."

URGENCY: REFER SAME-DAY

RED FLAGS IDENTIFIED: Possible TIA (transient ischemic attack) — misattributed to neck problems.

Clinical reasoning:
- Chronic neck pain is a separate, known condition
- BUT: episodic, SIMULTANEOUS arm + leg weakness on SAME side = not cervical radiculopathy
- Cervical radiculopathy: causes arm symptoms ALONE (single level), NOT arm+leg
- Ipsilateral arm + leg (hemiparesis) = central nervous system pathology
- Transient episodes (10-15 min) with full recovery = classic TIA
- TIA is warning sign for stroke (30% risk within 90 days without treatment)

ACTION: Do NOT perform cervical manipulation. Emergency department SAME DAY. CT/MRI brain, CT angiography neck vessels, ECG. Neurological assessment. Antiplatelet therapy may be needed.

Du er en medisinsk sikkerhetsrådgiver for kiropraktikk. Identifiser røde flagg, gi differensialdiagnostikk og klinisk resonnering. Prioriter alltid pasientsikkerhet. Klassifiser hastegrad: AKUTT (ring 113), HENVIS SAMME DAG, HENVIS RUTINE, MONITORÉR, eller TRYGT.
Vurder røde flagg: 52 år mann med akutt debut av svakhet i begge bena, nummenhet fra brystlinjen og ned, og vannlatingsproblemer etter å ha løftet tungt. Kjent torakal diskusherniering.

HASTEGRAD: AKUTT — Ring 113

RØDE FLAGG IDENTIFISERT: Akutt torakal myelopati.

Klinisk resonnering:
- Bilateral beinsvakhet med sensorisk nivå ved brystlinjen = torakal medullakompresjon
- Kjent torakal diskusherniering = anatomisk årsak identifisert
- Vannlatingsproblemer = sfinkteraffeksjon (alvorlig prognostisk markør)
- Akutt debut etter løfting = mulig akutt diskusherniering
- Torakal medullakompresjon har DÅRLIGERE prognose enn lumbal CES pga. ryggmargen

Dette er AKUTT: ryggmargen tolererer kompresjon dårligere enn cauda equina.

HANDLING: Ring 113. Akutt MR torakalcolumna. Nevrokirurgisk vurdering for dekompresjon. INGEN manipulasjon. Fullstendig immobilisering av thorakalcolumna.

Du er en medisinsk sikkerhetsrådgiver for kiropraktikk. Identifiser røde flagg, gi differensialdiagnostikk og klinisk resonnering. Prioriter alltid pasientsikkerhet. Klassifiser hastegrad: AKUTT (ring 113), HENVIS SAMME DAG, HENVIS RUTINE, MONITORÉR, eller TRYGT.
Vurder røde flagg: 55 år mann med akutt, ekstremt smertefullt, rødt og hovnet kne. Feber 38.5°C. Kan ikke belaste. Ingen forutgående traume.

HASTEGRAD: HENVIS SAMME DAG (akuttmottak)

RØDE FLAGG IDENTIFISERT: Akutt monoartritt — septisk artritt inntil det motsatte er bevist.

Klinisk resonnering:
- Akutt monoartritt med feber = septisk artritt FØRST i differensialdiagnosen
- Rubor + tumor + calor + dolor + functio laesa = klassisk akutt inflammasjon
- Septisk artritt er en KIRURGISK NØDSITUASJON (leddskylling)
- Urinsyregikt gir lignende bilde, men behandlingsforsinkling ved septisk artritt = leddødeleggelse
- Regel: "Hovent, varmt ledd med feber = leddpunksjon FØRST"
- Leddpunksjon skiller septisk artritt fra krystallartritt (gikt)

HANDLING: Akuttmottak SAMME DAG. Leddpunksjon for dyrkning og krystallundersøkelse. Blodkulturer. IKKE gi antibiotika før prøver er tatt. INGEN manuell behandling av leddet.

Du er en medisinsk sikkerhetsrådgiver for kiropraktikk. Identifiser røde flagg, gi differensialdiagnostikk og klinisk resonnering. Prioriter alltid pasientsikkerhet. Klassifiser hastegrad: AKUTT (ring 113), HENVIS SAMME DAG, HENVIS RUTINE, MONITORÉR, eller TRYGT.
Vurder røde flagg: 48 år kvinne med symmetrisk hevelse og smerter i MCP-ledd (2.-4. finger bilateralt) og PIP-ledd i 8 uker. Morgenstivhet 50 minutter. Tretthet. Ingen tidligere leddproblemer.

HASTEGRAD: HENVIS RUTINE (innen 2-4 uker)

Mistanke om revmatoid artritt (RA).

Klinisk resonnering:
- Symmetrisk polyartritt i MCP/PIP-ledd = klassisk for RA
- Morgenstivhet >30 min = inflammatorisk mønster (mekanisk: <30 min)
- Tretthet = systemisk inflammasjon
- Debut 48 år = typisk for RA (40-60 år)
- Ingen akutt fare, men TIDLIG behandling (innen 3 mnd) gir betydelig bedre langtidsprognose
- "Window of opportunity" = de første 3-6 månedene er kritiske for å forhindre ledderosjon

HANDLING: Blodprøver (anti-CCP, RF, CRP, SR, hematologi). Henvisning revmatolog innen 2-4 uker. Kiropraktisk behandling av nakke/rygg kan fortsette. IKKE manipuler hovne ledd direkte.

Du er en medisinsk sikkerhetsrådgiver for kiropraktikk. Identifiser røde flagg, gi differensialdiagnostikk og klinisk resonnering. Prioriter alltid pasientsikkerhet. Klassifiser hastegrad: AKUTT (ring 113), HENVIS SAMME DAG, HENVIS RUTINE, MONITORÉR, eller TRYGT.

Vurder røde flagg: 40 år mann med kronisk korsryggsmerte i 2 år. Har vært hos mange behandlere uten bedring. Katastrofetenkning ("ryggen min er ødelagt"). Unngår all fysisk aktivitet. Søvnproblemer. Sykemeldt 6 måneder.

HASTEGRAD: MONITORÉR — psykososiale gule flagg

Ingen røde flagg identifisert, men BETYDELIGE gule flagg.

Klinisk resonnering:
- Ingen nevrologiske utfall, ingen systemiske symptomer = ingen røde flagg
- Men GULE FLAGG som forutsier kronifisering og dårlig prognose:
  1. Katastrofetenkning ("ødelagt rygg") = kognitiv risikofaktor
  2. Unngåelsesatferd (fear-avoidance) = atferdsmessig risikofaktor
  3. Langvarig sykemelding (6 mnd) = sterk prediktor for permanent uførhet
  4. Søvnforstyrrelser = opprettholdende faktor
  5. Multiple mislykkede behandlinger = mulig feil tilnærming

Dette er IKKE en nødsituasjon, men krever endret behandlingstilnærming.

HANDLING: Gradert aktivitetstilnærming, IKKE smerteavhengig. Kognitiv tilnærming til katastrofetenkning. Tverrfaglig smerteklinikk-henvisning. Edukasjon om smerte. Samarbeid med fastlege om arbeidsrettet rehabilitering.

You are a medical safety advisor for chiropractic. Identify red flags, provide differential diagnosis and clinical reasoning. Always prioritize patient safety. Classify urgency: URGENT (call ambulance), REFER SAME-DAY, REFER ROUTINE, MONITOR, or SAFE.
Assess red flags: 52-year-old male with acute onset bilateral leg weakness, numbness from chest level down, and urinary difficulty after heavy lifting. Known thoracic disc herniation.

URGENCY: URGENT — Call emergency services

RED FLAGS IDENTIFIED: Acute thoracic myelopathy.

Clinical reasoning:
- Bilateral leg weakness with sensory level at chest = thoracic cord compression
- Known thoracic disc herniation = anatomical cause identified
- Urinary difficulty = sphincter involvement (severe prognostic marker)
- Acute onset after lifting = possible acute disc herniation
- Thoracic cord compression has WORSE prognosis than lumbar CES because of spinal cord

This is ACUTE: the spinal cord tolerates compression worse than cauda equina.

ACTION: Call emergency services. Urgent MRI thoracic spine. Neurosurgical evaluation for decompression. NO manipulation. Complete thoracic spine immobilization.

You are a medical safety advisor for chiropractic. Identify red flags, provide differential diagnosis and clinical reasoning. Always prioritize patient safety. Classify urgency: URGENT (call ambulance), REFER SAME-DAY, REFER ROUTINE, MONITOR, or SAFE.
Assess red flags: 55-year-old male with acute, extremely painful, red and swollen knee. Fever 38.5C. Cannot weight-bear. No preceding trauma.

URGENCY: REFER SAME-DAY (emergency department)

RED FLAGS IDENTIFIED: Acute monoarthritis — septic arthritis until proven otherwise.

Clinical reasoning:
- Acute monoarthritis with fever = septic arthritis FIRST in differential
- Redness + swelling + warmth + pain + loss of function = classic acute inflammation
- Septic arthritis is a SURGICAL EMERGENCY (joint washout)
- Gout can look similar, but delayed treatment of septic arthritis = joint destruction
- Rule: "Hot, swollen joint with fever = joint aspiration FIRST"
- Joint aspiration distinguishes septic arthritis from crystal arthritis (gout)

ACTION: Emergency department SAME DAY. Joint aspiration for culture and crystal analysis. Blood cultures. Do NOT give antibiotics before samples taken. NO manual treatment of the joint.

Assess red flags: 48-year-old female with symmetric swelling and pain in MCP joints (2nd-4th finger bilaterally) and PIP joints for 8 weeks. Morning stiffness 50 minutes. Fatigue. No previous joint problems.

URGENCY: REFER ROUTINE (within 2-4 weeks)

Suspected rheumatoid arthritis (RA).

Clinical reasoning:
- Symmetric polyarthritis in MCP/PIP joints = classic for RA
- Morning stiffness >30 min = inflammatory pattern (mechanical: <30 min)
- Fatigue = systemic inflammation
- Onset age 48 = typical for RA (40-60 years)
- No acute danger, but EARLY treatment (within 3 months) gives significantly better long-term prognosis
- "Window of opportunity" = first 3-6 months are critical to prevent joint erosion

ACTION: Blood work (anti-CCP, RF, CRP, ESR, CBC). Rheumatology referral within 2-4 weeks. Chiropractic treatment of neck/back can continue. Do NOT manipulate swollen joints directly.

You are a medical safety advisor for chiropractic. Identify red flags, provide differential diagnosis and clinical reasoning. Always prioritize patient safety. Classify urgency: URGENT (call ambulance), REFER SAME-DAY, REFER ROUTINE, MONITOR, or SAFE.

Assess red flags: 40-year-old male with chronic low back pain for 2 years. Seen many practitioners without improvement. Catastrophizing ("my back is broken"). Avoids all physical activity. Sleep problems. On sick leave for 6 months.

URGENCY: MONITOR — psychosocial yellow flags

No red flags identified, but SIGNIFICANT yellow flags.

Clinical reasoning:
- No neurological deficits, no systemic symptoms = no red flags
- But YELLOW FLAGS predicting chronification and poor prognosis:
  1. Catastrophizing ("broken back") = cognitive risk factor
  2. Avoidance behavior (fear-avoidance) = behavioral risk factor
  3. Prolonged sick leave (6 months) = strong predictor of permanent disability
  4. Sleep disturbance = maintaining factor
  5. Multiple failed treatments = possibly wrong approach

This is NOT an emergency, but requires a changed treatment approach.

ACTION: Graded activity approach, NOT pain-contingent. Cognitive approach to catastrophizing. Multidisciplinary pain clinic referral. Pain education. Collaborate with GP on vocational rehabilitation.

Du er en medisinsk sikkerhetsrådgiver for kiropraktikk. Identifiser røde flagg, gi differensialdiagnostikk og klinisk resonnering. Prioriter alltid pasientsikkerhet. Klassifiser hastegrad: AKUTT (ring 113), HENVIS SAMME DAG, HENVIS RUTINE, MONITORÉR, eller TRYGT.

Vurder røde flagg: 60 år mann med kjent spinal stenose. Har hatt bilateral claudicatio i år. I dag rapporterer han at han de siste dagene har hatt redusert evne til å kontrollere avføring. Ingen endring i ryggsmerter.

HASTEGRAD: AKUTT — Ring 113

RØDE FLAGG IDENTIFISERT: Mulig cauda equina syndrom — sfinkteraffeksjon ved kjent stenose.

Klinisk resonnering:
- Pasienten har KJENT stenose med langvarig claudicatio — dette er hans "baseline"
- NY sfinkteraffeksjon (fekal inkontinens) = ny nevrologisk forverring
- Fekal inkontinens er et SENT tegn på CES (mer alarmerende enn urinretensjon alene)
- At ryggsmerter er UENDRET betyr ingenting — CES kan progrediere uten smerteforverring
- Kjent stenose = anatomisk substrat for akutt kompresjon

Viktig lærdom: Ny sfinkteraffeksjon hos pasient med kjent stenose = CES uavhengig av smertenivå.

HANDLING: Ring 113. Akutt MR. Nevrokirurgisk tilsyn for dekompresjon.

Du er en medisinsk sikkerhetsrådgiver for kiropraktikk. Identifiser røde flagg, gi differensialdiagnostikk og klinisk resonnering. Prioriter alltid pasientsikkerhet. Klassifiser hastegrad: AKUTT (ring 113), HENVIS SAMME DAG, HENVIS RUTINE, MONITORÉR, eller TRYGT.

Vurder røde flagg: 45 år kvinne, snekker. Bilateral nummenhet i 4. og 5. finger etter langvarig bruk av vibrerende verktøy. Verst etter arbeid. Tinel positiv i begge Guyons kanaler. Normal kraft. Normal gange.

HASTEGRAD: TRYGT

Ingen røde flagg identifisert.

Klinisk resonnering — hvorfor bilateral fingerummenhet IKKE er myelopati:
- Nummenhet begrenset til ulnarisnerven (4.-5. finger) = perifer entrapment
- Guyon kanal-kompresjon er kjent yrkessykdom hos snekkere (vibrasjon + grep)
- Myelopati: ville gitt bredere distribusjon, IKKE isolert til ulnaris-territoriet
- Positiv Tinel bilateralt bekrefter PERIFER nervekompresjon
- Normal kraft og gange = ingen sentral patologi
- Vibrerende verktøy som utløser = klar yrkesrelatert årsak

Klinisk bilde: Bilateral ulnar neuropati i Guyons kanal (yrkesrelatert).

Trygt å behandle med ergonomisk rådgivning, vibrasjonsdemping, nervegliding.

Du er en medisinsk sikkerhetsrådgiver for kiropraktikk. Identifiser røde flagg, gi differensialdiagnostikk og klinisk resonnering. Prioriter alltid pasientsikkerhet. Klassifiser hastegrad: AKUTT (ring 113), HENVIS SAMME DAG, HENVIS RUTINE, MONITORÉR, eller TRYGT.

Vurder røde flagg: 50 år kvinne med svimmelhet utløst av nakkerotasjon. Ingen spontannystagmus. Negativ Dix-Hallpike. Ingen hørselstap. Nakkesmerte og redusert ROM. Svimmelheten er kortvarig (<30 sek) og alltid relatert til nakkebevegelse.

HASTEGRAD: TRYGT

Ingen røde flagg identifisert.

Klinisk resonnering — hvorfor denne svimmelheten er cervikal og IKKE sentral:
- Utløst kun ved nakkebevegelse (cervikogent mønster)
- Negativ Dix-Hallpike (utelukker BPPV)
- Ingen spontannystagmus (sentral patologi gir ofte spontannystagmus)
- Kortvarig (<30 sek) og REPRODUSERBAR ved nakke-rotasjon
- Ingen hørselstap (utelukker Ménière)
- Fravær av sentrale tegn: ingen diplopi, ingen dysartri, ingen dysfagi, ingen ataksi

Sentral svimmelhet (vertebrobasilær insuffisiens):
- Ville gitt tilleggssymptomer (5 D-er: dizziness, diplopia, dysarthria, dysphagia, drop attacks)
- Ville vært UPROVOSERT eller ved spesielle hodestillinger

Klinisk bilde: Cervikogen svimmelhet.

Trygt å behandle med cervikal mobilisering, vestibulær rehabilitering, øvelser.

Du er en medisinsk sikkerhetsrådgiver for kiropraktikk. Identifiser røde flagg, gi differensialdiagnostikk og klinisk resonnering. Prioriter alltid pasientsikkerhet. Klassifiser hastegrad: AKUTT (ring 113), HENVIS SAMME DAG, HENVIS RUTINE, MONITORÉR, eller TRYGT.

Vurder røde flagg: 35 år mann med kjent migrene i 15 år. Rapporterer at migreneanfallene hans har endret karakter de siste 2 månedene: hyppigere (fra 2/mnd til 8/mnd), lengre varighet, og nå også hodepine mellom anfallene. Ellers frisk.

HASTEGRAD: MONITORÉR — endret hodepine-mønster

Ingen akutte røde flagg, men ENDRET mønster krever utredning.

Klinisk resonnering:
- Kjent migrene i 15 år = etablert diagnose
- MEN: ENDRING i mønster er alarmsignal ved kjent hodepine:
  1. Økt frekvens (2→8/mnd) = kronifisering
  2. Lengre varighet = endret sykdomsaktivitet
  3. Interiktal hodepine (mellom anfall) = ny hodepine-type

Mulige forklaringer (rangert):
1. Medikamentoverforbrukshodepine (MOH) — sjekk analgetika-bruk
2. Kronisk migrene (>15 dager/mnd) — krever profylaktisk behandling
3. Ny sekundær hodepine (sjeldnere, men MÅ utelukkes ved endret mønster)

HANDLING: Hodepinedagbok i 4 uker. Kartlegg medikamentbruk. Henvisning nevrolog for revurdering innen 4-6 uker. Fortsett cervikal behandling, men dokumentér hodepine-respons grundig.

Du er en medisinsk sikkerhetsrådgiver for kiropraktikk. Identifiser røde flagg, gi differensialdiagnostikk og klinisk resonnering. Prioriter alltid pasientsikkerhet. Klassifiser hastegrad: AKUTT (ring 113), HENVIS SAMME DAG, HENVIS RUTINE, MONITORÉR, eller TRYGT.

Vurder røde flagg: 48 år mann med akutt torticollis etter å ha snudd seg brått i bilen. Smerter venstre side nakke, redusert rotasjon til venstre. Full kraft i armer. Normale reflekser. Ingen hodepine. Ingen svimmelhet. Ingen synsforstyrrelser.

HASTEGRAD: TRYGT

Ingen røde flagg identifisert.

Systematisk rød-flagg screening:

✗ Vaskulær: Ingen hodepine, ingen svimmelhet, ingen synsforstyrrelser, ingen Horners tegn → UTELUKKET
✗ Fraktur: Ikke høyenergitraume (bilrotasjon ≠ kollisjon), ingen fokal perkusjonsømhet → UTELUKKET
✗ Infeksjon: Ingen feber, ingen nattsvette, ingen immunsuppresjon → UTELUKKET
✗ Malignitet: Under 50, ingen vekttap, ingen tidligere kreft → UTELUKKET
✗ Myelopati: Full kraft bilateralt, normale reflekser, normal gange → UTELUKKET
✗ Radikulopati: Ingen utstråling til arm, normal sensibilitet → UTELUKKET

Klinisk bilde: Akutt mekanisk torticollis.

Trygt å behandle med forsiktig mobilisering, varme, NSAID ved behov. Forventet bedring 3-7 dager.

You are a medical safety advisor for chiropractic. Identify red flags, provide differential diagnosis and clinical reasoning. Always prioritize patient safety. Classify urgency: URGENT (call ambulance), REFER SAME-DAY, REFER ROUTINE, MONITOR, or SAFE.

Assess red flags: 60-year-old male with known spinal stenosis. Has had bilateral claudication for years. Today reports reduced ability to control bowel movements over past few days. No change in back pain.

URGENCY: URGENT — Call emergency services

RED FLAGS IDENTIFIED: Possible cauda equina syndrome — sphincter involvement in known stenosis.

Clinical reasoning:
- Patient has KNOWN stenosis with longstanding claudication — this is his "baseline"
- NEW sphincter dysfunction (fecal incontinence) = new neurological deterioration
- Fecal incontinence is a LATE sign of CES (more alarming than urinary retention alone)
- That back pain is UNCHANGED is irrelevant — CES can progress without pain worsening
- Known stenosis = anatomical substrate for acute compression

Key lesson: New sphincter dysfunction in patient with known stenosis = CES regardless of pain level.

ACTION: Call emergency services. Urgent MRI. Neurosurgical consultation for decompression.

You are a medical safety advisor for chiropractic. Identify red flags, provide differential diagnosis and clinical reasoning. Always prioritize patient safety. Classify urgency: URGENT (call ambulance), REFER SAME-DAY, REFER ROUTINE, MONITOR, or SAFE.

Assess red flags: 45-year-old female carpenter. Bilateral numbness in 4th and 5th fingers after prolonged use of vibrating tools. Worst after work. Positive Tinel at both Guyon canals. Normal strength. Normal gait.

URGENCY: SAFE

No red flags identified.

Clinical reasoning — why bilateral finger numbness is NOT myelopathy:
- Numbness limited to ulnar nerve (4th-5th finger) = peripheral entrapment
- Guyon canal compression is known occupational disease in carpenters (vibration + grip)
- Myelopathy: would cause broader distribution, NOT isolated to ulnar territory
- Positive bilateral Tinel confirms PERIPHERAL nerve compression
- Normal strength and gait = no central pathology
- Vibrating tools as trigger = clear occupational cause

Clinical picture: Bilateral ulnar neuropathy at Guyon canal (occupational).

Safe to treat with ergonomic advice, vibration dampening, nerve gliding exercises.

You are a medical safety advisor for chiropractic. Identify red flags, provide differential diagnosis and clinical reasoning. Always prioritize patient safety. Classify urgency: URGENT (call ambulance), REFER SAME-DAY, REFER ROUTINE, MONITOR, or SAFE.

Assess red flags: 50-year-old female with dizziness triggered by neck rotation. No spontaneous nystagmus. Negative Dix-Hallpike. No hearing loss. Neck pain and reduced ROM. Dizziness is brief (<30 sec) and always related to neck movement.

URGENCY: SAFE

No red flags identified.

Clinical reasoning — why this dizziness is cervical and NOT central:
- Triggered only by neck movement (cervicogenic pattern)
- Negative Dix-Hallpike (rules out BPPV)
- No spontaneous nystagmus (central pathology often causes spontaneous nystagmus)
- Brief (<30 sec) and REPRODUCIBLE with neck rotation
- No hearing loss (rules out Meniere)
- Absence of central signs: no diplopia, no dysarthria, no dysphagia, no ataxia

Central dizziness (vertebrobasilar insufficiency):
- Would cause additional symptoms (5 Ds: dizziness, diplopia, dysarthria, dysphagia, drop attacks)
- Would be UNPROVOKED or with specific head positions

Clinical picture: Cervicogenic dizziness.

Safe to treat with cervical mobilization, vestibular rehabilitation, exercises.

You are a medical safety advisor for chiropractic. Identify red flags, provide differential diagnosis and clinical reasoning. Always prioritize patient safety. Classify urgency: URGENT (call ambulance), REFER SAME-DAY, REFER ROUTINE, MONITOR, or SAFE.

Assess red flags: 35-year-old male with known migraine for 15 years. Reports migraines have changed character over past 2 months: more frequent (from 2/month to 8/month), longer duration, and now headache between attacks too. Otherwise healthy.

URGENCY: MONITOR — changed headache pattern

No acute red flags, but CHANGED pattern requires investigation.

Clinical reasoning:
- Known migraine for 15 years = established diagnosis
- BUT: CHANGE in pattern is alarm signal in known headache:
  1. Increased frequency (2→8/month) = chronification
  2. Longer duration = changed disease activity
  3. Interictal headache (between attacks) = new headache type

Possible explanations (ranked):
1. Medication overuse headache (MOH) — check analgesic use
2. Chronic migraine (>15 days/month) — requires prophylactic treatment
3. New secondary headache (rarer, but MUST be excluded with changed pattern)

ACTION: Headache diary for 4 weeks. Map medication use. Neurology referral for reassessment within 4-6 weeks. Continue cervical treatment, but document headache response thoroughly.

You are a medical safety advisor for chiropractic. Identify red flags, provide differential diagnosis and clinical reasoning. Always prioritize patient safety. Classify urgency: URGENT (call ambulance), REFER SAME-DAY, REFER ROUTINE, MONITOR, or SAFE.

Assess red flags: 48-year-old male with acute torticollis after turning suddenly in car. Left-sided neck pain, reduced left rotation. Full arm strength. Normal reflexes. No headache. No dizziness. No visual disturbances.

URGENCY: SAFE

No red flags identified.

Systematic red flag screening:

✗ Vascular: No headache, no dizziness, no visual disturbances, no Horner signs → EXCLUDED
✗ Fracture: Not high-energy trauma (car turning ≠ collision), no focal percussion tenderness → EXCLUDED
✗ Infection: No fever, no night sweats, no immunosuppression → EXCLUDED
✗ Malignancy: Under 50, no weight loss, no cancer history → EXCLUDED
✗ Myelopathy: Full bilateral strength, normal reflexes, normal gait → EXCLUDED
✗ Radiculopathy: No arm radiation, normal sensation → EXCLUDED

Clinical picture: Acute mechanical torticollis.

Safe to treat with gentle mobilization, heat, NSAID if needed. Expected improvement 3-7 days.

You are a medical safety advisor for chiropractic. Identify red flags, provide differential diagnosis and clinical reasoning. Always prioritize patient safety. Classify urgency: URGENT (call ambulance), REFER SAME-DAY, REFER ROUTINE, MONITOR, or SAFE.

Assess red flags: 55-year-old male with chronic mid-back pain, comes for usual treatment. In waiting room, experienced what wife describes as a brief seizure — stiffened, fell from chair, tonic-clonic movements for 30 seconds. Now confused and drowsy.

URGENCY: URGENT — Call emergency services

RED FLAGS IDENTIFIED: New-onset seizure — requires emergent evaluation.

Clinical reasoning:
- New-onset seizure in adult = NEVER benign until proven otherwise
- In context of back pain: could indicate spinal/intracranial metastasis with seizure
- Post-ictal confusion and drowsiness = consistent with generalized seizure
- Differential for new seizure at age 55: brain metastasis, primary brain tumor, vascular event
- Back pain + seizure in older adult = concerning for metastatic disease

This is a medical emergency regardless of back pain history.

ACTION: Call emergency services. Keep patient safe (recovery position). Do not restrain. CT brain urgently. Monitor airway and consciousness. Do NOT attempt any manual treatment. This patient needs emergency department evaluation.

You are a medical safety advisor for chiropractic. Identify red flags, provide differential diagnosis and clinical reasoning. Always prioritize patient safety. Classify urgency: URGENT (call ambulance), REFER SAME-DAY, REFER ROUTINE, MONITOR, or SAFE.

Assess red flags: 42-year-old female teacher with 3-year history of chronic neck and shoulder pain. Reports occasional tingling in fingers when working overhead. Symptoms always resolve within minutes. Full strength, normal reflexes. No clumsiness. Pain varies with work load.

URGENCY: SAFE

No red flags identified.

Clinical reasoning:
- Chronic neck/shoulder pain with clear occupational trigger (teaching = overhead, sustained postures)
- Occasional finger tingling with overhead work = thoracic outlet-type provocation or cervical foraminal narrowing
- Key reassuring features:
  1. Symptoms ALWAYS resolve within minutes (transient, positional)
  2. Full strength (no motor deficit)
  3. Normal reflexes (no myelopathy signs)
  4. No clumsiness (no upper motor neuron involvement)
  5. Pain varies with workload (mechanical correlation)
- Myelopathy tingling would be PERSISTENT, not positional and transient
- 3-year stable history without progression = benign natural history

Clinical picture: Chronic mechanical cervicothoracic pain with positional neurocompressive symptoms.

Safe to treat with thoracic outlet stretches, cervical mobilization, postural strengthening, ergonomic modification for classroom.

Vurder røde flagg: 30 år kvinne med akutt korsryggsmerte etter kettlebell-trening. Bilateral muskelstramhet i paraspinale muskler. Kan ikke bøye seg forover. Ingen utstråling. Normal kraft, reflekser og sensibilitet. Vannlating normal.

Ingen røde flagg identifisert.

Klinisk resonnering — systematisk sjekkliste:
✗ CES: Ingen sadelanestesi, normal vannlating, ingen bilateral svakhet → UTELUKKET
✗ Fraktur: Ung uten osteoporose, ikke fall/traume, ingen perkusjonsømhet → UTELUKKET
✗ Infeksjon: Ingen feber, ingen nattsvette, ingen immunsuppresjon → UTELUKKET
✗ Kreft: 30 år, ingen vekttap, ingen tidligere kreft → UTELUKKET

Bilateral muskelstramhet etter intens trening er NORMALT — ikke forveksle med bilateral nevrologisk affeksjon.

Trygt å behandle med mobilisering, aktive øvelser, gradert belastning.

Vurder røde flagg: 55 år kvinne med plutselig synstap på høyre øye siste 24 timer. Nakkesmerte siste uken. Ingen hodepine, ingen tinningsømhet. Normal temporal arteriepulsasjon.

HASTEGRAD: AKUTT — Akuttmottak

RØDE FLAGG IDENTIFISERT: Akutt monokulært synstap.

Klinisk resonnering:
- Plutselig synstap = øyemedisinsk/nevrologisk akuttsituasjon UANSETT årsak
- Mulige årsaker: retinal arterieokklusjon, optikusnevritt, GCA (selv uten typiske symptomer)
- Fravær av tinningsømhet og hodepine utelukker IKKE GCA — opptil 20% har atypisk presentasjon
- Nakkesmerte + synstap kan også indikere carotisdisseksjon med retinal emboli

HANDLING: Akuttmottak/øyelegevakt UMIDDELBART. SR/CRP akutt (GCA-screening). Oftalmoskopi. CT-angiografi halskar. Ikke utfør cervikal behandling.

Vurder røde flagg: 43 år mann med mekanisk brystryggsmerte etter fallskjermhopping for 2 dager siden. Smerter mellom skulderbladene. Reproduserbar ved rotasjon og palpasjon. Normal pust, normal SpO2. Ingen nevrologiske symptomer.

HASTEGRAD: MONITORÉR

Ingen akutte røde flagg, men OBS fallskjermhopping = betydelig aksial belastning.

Klinisk resonnering:
- Smerter er reproduserbare = mekanisk komponent bekreftet
- Normal pust og SpO2 = ingen pneumothorax/lungepatologi
- Ingen nevrologiske symptomer = ingen medullakompresjon
- MEN: fallskjermhopping = betydelig aksial belastning ved landing
- Kompresjonsfraktur kan ha subtil presentasjon initialt

Forsiktighetstiltak:
- Palpér hvert segment for fokal perkusjonsømhet (vs. diffus muskulær ømhet)
- Ved ENHVER fokal ømhet over processus spinosus → røntgen

HANDLING: Forsiktig behandling. Røntgen thorakalcolumna anbefales pga. traumemekanisme. Revurder om 3-5 dager.

Vurder røde flagg: 68 år kvinne med akutt hoftesmerte etter å ha snublet i teppet. Kan belaste men med smerter. Forkortet og utadrotert bein. Kjent osteoporose.

HASTEGRAD: HENVIS SAMME DAG

RØDE FLAGG IDENTIFISERT: Sannsynlig hoftefraktur.

Klinisk resonnering:
- Forkortet og utadrotert bein etter fall = klassisk for collum femoris-fraktur
- At hun KAN belaste utelukker IKKE fraktur — uforskyvet fraktur tillater vektbelastning
- Kjent osteoporose = høy frakturrisiko selv ved lavenergitraume (snubling)
- Alder >65 + fall + osteoporose + klinisk deformitet = fraktur til det motsatte er bevist

HANDLING: Akutt røntgen hofte (to plan). Ortopedisk vurdering SAMME DAG. Smertelindring. Avlast vekt. INGEN hoftemobilisering.

Klinisk resonnering — systematisk inflammatorisk screening:

- MEN: morgenstivhet 20 min < 30 min-grensen
- Ingen nattlige smerter
- Normale inflammasjonsmarkører (CRP, SR)
- Negativ HLA-B27 (reduserer sannsynligheten for Bekhterev med ~90%)

Inflammatorisk ryggsmerte UTELUKKET basert på:
1. Kort morgenstivhet (<30 min)
2. Ingen nattlige smerter
3. Normale blodprøver
4. Negativ HLA-B27

Klinisk bilde: Mekanisk korsryggsmerte hos ung aktiv mann.

Trygt å behandle konservativt med stabiliserende øvelser og treningsveiledning.

You are a medical safety advisor for chiropractic. Identify red flags, provide differential diagnosis and clinical reasoning. Always prioritize patient safety. Classify urgency: URGENT (call ambulance), REFER SAME-DAY, REFER ROUTINE, MONITOR, or SAFE.
Assess red flags: 75-year-old male with acute confusion, neck stiffness, fever 39C, photophobia. Brought in by family. Known chronic low back pain.

URGENCY: URGENT — Call emergency services

RED FLAGS IDENTIFIED: Suspected meningitis.

Clinical reasoning:
- The triad: neck stiffness + fever + confusion = meningitis until proven otherwise
- Photophobia confirms meningeal irritation
- The low back pain is IRRELEVANT — this is a life-threatening infection
- Elderly are more susceptible to severe course
- The neck stiffness is NOT muscular — it is meningism (involuntary neck resistance)

ACTION: Call emergency services IMMEDIATELY. Lumbar puncture and blood cultures at hospital. Antibiotics within 1 hour of arrival. NO manual treatment.

Assess red flags: 30-year-old female with acute low back pain after kettlebell training. Bilateral paraspinal muscle tightness. Cannot bend forward. No radiation. Normal strength, reflexes and sensation. Normal urination.

URGENCY: SAFE

No red flags identified.

Clinical reasoning — systematic checklist:
✗ CES: No saddle anesthesia, normal urination, no bilateral weakness → EXCLUDED
✗ Fracture: Young without osteoporosis, no fall/trauma, no percussion tenderness → EXCLUDED
✗ Infection: No fever, no night sweats, no immunosuppression → EXCLUDED
✗ Cancer: Age 30, no weight loss, no cancer history → EXCLUDED

Bilateral muscle tightness after intense training is NORMAL — do not confuse with bilateral neurological involvement.

Safe to treat with mobilization, active exercises, graded loading.

Assess red flags: 55-year-old female with sudden vision loss in right eye over past 24 hours. Neck pain for the past week. No headache, no temporal tenderness. Normal temporal artery pulsation.

URGENCY: URGENT — Emergency department

RED FLAGS IDENTIFIED: Acute monocular vision loss.

Clinical reasoning:
- Sudden vision loss = ophthalmological/neurological emergency REGARDLESS of cause
- Possible causes: retinal artery occlusion, optic neuritis, GCA (even without typical symptoms)
- Absence of temporal tenderness and headache does NOT exclude GCA — up to 20% have atypical presentation
- Neck pain + vision loss can also indicate carotid dissection with retinal emboli

ACTION: Emergency department/eye emergency IMMEDIATELY. Urgent ESR/CRP (GCA screening). Ophthalmoscopy. CT angiography neck vessels. Do not perform cervical treatment.

Assess red flags: 68-year-old female with acute hip pain after tripping on carpet. Can weight-bear but painful. Shortened and externally rotated leg. Known osteoporosis.

URGENCY: REFER SAME-DAY

RED FLAGS IDENTIFIED: Probable hip fracture.

Clinical reasoning:
- Shortened and externally rotated leg after fall = classic for femoral neck fracture
- Being ABLE to weight-bear does NOT exclude fracture — undisplaced fracture allows weight-bearing
- Known osteoporosis = high fracture risk even with low-energy trauma (tripping)
- Age >65 + fall + osteoporosis + clinical deformity = fracture until proven otherwise

ACTION: Urgent hip X-ray (two views). Orthopedic assessment SAME DAY. Pain management. Non-weight-bearing. NO hip mobilization.

- Age <40 with back pain >3 months ✓ (triggers inflammatory screening)
- BUT: morning stiffness 20 min < 30 min threshold
- No night pain
- Normal inflammatory markers (CRP, ESR)
- Negative HLA-B27 (reduces probability of AS by ~90%)

Inflammatory back pain EXCLUDED based on:
1. Short morning stiffness (<30 min)
2. No night pain
3. Normal blood work
4. Negative HLA-B27

Clinical picture: Mechanical low back pain in young active male.

Safe to treat conservatively with stabilization exercises and training guidance.

Assess red flags: 43-year-old male with mechanical thoracic back pain after skydiving 2 days ago. Pain between shoulder blades. Reproducible with rotation and palpation. Normal breathing, normal SpO2. No neurological symptoms.

URGENCY: MONITOR

No acute red flags, but NOTE: skydiving = significant axial loading.

Clinical reasoning:
- Pain is reproducible = mechanical component confirmed
- Normal breathing and SpO2 = no pneumothorax/pulmonary pathology
- No neurological symptoms = no cord compression
- BUT: skydiving = significant axial loading at landing
- Compression fracture can have subtle initial presentation

Precaution:
- Palpate each segment for focal percussion tenderness (vs. diffuse muscular soreness)
- If ANY focal tenderness over spinous process → X-ray

ACTION: Gentle treatment. Thoracic spine X-ray recommended due to trauma mechanism. Reassess in 3-5 days.
